code: @Manual{,   title = {psymetadata: Open Datasets from Meta-Analyses in Psychology Research},   author = {Josue E. Rodriguez and Donald Williams and Lukas Wallrich},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 1.0.2},   url = {https://josue-rodriguez.github.io/psymetadata/}, }

what: Open Datasets from Meta-Analyses in Psychology Research
title: Open Datasets from Meta-Analyses in Psychology Research
text: data package provides open datasets meta-analyses different areas psychological science.

title: Open Datasets from Meta-Analyses in Psychology Research
text: can install released version psymetadata CRAN : want install recent development version GitHub, use following code:

title: Open Datasets from Meta-Analyses in Psychology Research
text: ’d like contribute dataset package please following steps:

title: Open Datasets from Meta-Analyses in Psychology Research
text: Clone repository local machine

title: Open Datasets from Meta-Analyses in Psychology Research
text: Clean dataset type data.frame least following columns: study_id: unique id study es_id: unique id effect size (applicable) yi: effect size vi: variance effect size Column names follow snake case formatting. can easily done calling janitor::clean_names() data set. Feel free include many moderators additional columns like.

title: Open Datasets from Meta-Analyses in Psychology Research
text: Assign dataset object format [firstauthor][year] save data folder format [firstauthor][year].rda, e.g. curry2015 dataset originally collected publication Curry, Thompson, Green (2015)

title: Open Datasets from Meta-Analyses in Psychology Research
text: Add bibtex reference inst/REFERENCES.bib file. can easily obtained citation manager (e.g., Zotero) Google scholar

title: Open Datasets from Meta-Analyses in Psychology Research
text: Document dataset bottom R/data.R file. documentation roughly follow format: Take look data.R file examples
code: #' @title [Title] #' #' @description Results from [# of studies] studies, including [# of effect sizes] effect  #' sizes ([type of effect size]), on [short description of studies] \insertCite{[cite key]}{psymetadata}. #' #' @format A data frame with [# of rows] rows and [# of columns] variables: #' #' * \code{yi}: [description] #' * \code{vi}: [description] #' * \code{study_id}: [description] #' * \code{es_id}: [description] #' * \code{moderator1}: [description] #' * \code{moderator2}: [description] #' #' #' @md #' #' @details Further details can be found at \href{[link]}{[link]} #' #' @usage data("[dataset]") #' #' @references #' \insertAllCited{} "[dataset]"

title: Open Datasets from Meta-Analyses in Psychology Research
text: Submit pull request

title: Studies examining whether student emotional intelligence is associated with academic performance — maccann2020
Studies examining whether student emotional intelligence is associated with academic performance — maccann2020
text: data frame 1246 rows 19 variables: study_id: unique id study sample_id: unique id sample es_id: unique id effect size author: author study pub_year: year study publication yi: effect size (r) vi: sampling variance effect (SE^2) pub_type: publication type (0 = journal article, 1 = dissertation, 2 = conference proceedings, 3 = unpublished data) n: number participants contributing  effect size ed_level1: level education sample time data collection (0 = primary, 1 = secondary, 2 = tertiary, 3 = mixed) ed_level2: level education based type academic achievement reported (0 = primary, 1 = secondary, 2 = tertiary, 3 = mixed) country: country participants studies perc_white: percentage sample categorized "white" (USA samples ) age: mean age sample perc_female: percentage sample female ei_construct: EI facet construct represented (0 = overall ei, 2 = perception, 2 = facilitation, 3 = understanding, 4 = management, 5 = intrapersonal, 6 = interpersonal, 7 = stress management, 8 = adaptability, 9 = general mood) ei_stream: stream (type) EI instrument used (1 = maximum-performance ability tests, 2 = rating scales based ability models, 3 = broader models EI include non-ability constructs) ei_measure: test EI used (1.1 = MSCEIT, 1.2 = MEIS, 1.3 = DANVA, 1.4 = STEU, 1.5 = STEM, 2.1 = SUEIT, 2.2 = SSRI, 2.3 = SREIT, 2.4 = TMMS, 2.5 = WLEIS, 3.1 = EQi, 3.2 = TEIQue, 3.3 = ESAP) subject: subject area academic performance (0 = general, 1 = verbal/language arts, 2 = math, 3 = science, 4 = social studies, 5 = foreign language, 6 = psychology, 7 = medicine, 8 = engineering, 9 = physical education, 10 = art) humanities: subject area acadmeic performance, categorized sciences versus humanities (0 = general, 1 = math sciences, 2 = humanities verbal abilities) achievement_type: type achievement (0 = course grade, 1 = standardized test)

text: data frame 133 rows 23 variables: id: unique id study effect_id: unique id effect author: author study pub_year: year publication pub_type: publication type (1 = journal article, 2 = book chapter, 3 = dissertation, 4 = master's thesis, 5 = bachelor's thesis, 6 = conference proceedings, 7 = report, 8 = (eg., unpublished manuscript)) peer_review: whether publication peer-reviewed (0 = , 1 = yes) n: sample size effect size yi: effect size (r) vi: sampling variance (SE^2) adapt_measures: assessment method(s) adaptation used study (1 = self-report, 2 = people, 3 = objective, 4 = mixed) adapt_method: assessment method adaption (1 = subjective ratings, 2 = objective scores) adapt_method_specific: specific assessement method adaptation used particular effect size (1 = self-report, 2 = people, 3 = objective) subj_adapt_definition: definition subjective ratings performance adaptations ("narrow" "broad") cog_abil_measure: measurement method cognitive abilities ca_measure: categorized measure cognitive abilities ("general", "specific" "ACT/SAT/GPA") financ_support: financial support (e.g., grant; 0 = , 1 = yes) sex: sex (1 = female sample, 2 = male sample, 3 = mixed sample) men_prop: proportion men sample country: country sample sample: sample type (1 = students, 2 = employees, 3 = manager, 4 = mixed, 5 = ) task: task used measure performance adaptation ("simulation/video game", "SJT", "") complexity_component: coordinative complexity task (0 = relatively low, 1 = relatively high) complexity_coordinative: dynamic complexity task (0 = relatively low, 1 = relatively high)
